feed.title: Combined summary - Lamport scheme (not signature) to economize on L1

entry.title: Combined summary - Lamport scheme (not signature) to economize on L1
entry.summary:
Recent cryptographic discussions have proposed enhancements to system security and the efficiency of blockchain transactions. One proposal involves using nonces from recent blocks as salts in signing algorithms, which would incorporate 256 bits of entropy and utilize the inherent entropy in ECC public keys to combat rainbow-table attacks. The consensus on hash functions suggests that digest sizes should be double the encryption key size to address the birthday paradox, with a reluctance to reduce hash sizes due to the risk of making it economically viable for adversaries to perform such attacks in light of advancing storage technology.
Standardizing fingerprint bit lengths at 128 bits has been considered to maintain security while conserving space within transactions. Schnorr keys, compatible with this standardization, are being examined for their balance between protection and entropy derivation costs. To improve transaction reliability and prevent accidental defaults, a fixed interval between T0 and T2 (48 hours) has been set for transaction timing.
The Lamport scheme's usage in cryptocurrency transactions was discussed, focusing on its comparable on-chain footprint to Taproot's Schnorr keys when additional overheads are considered. Cryptocurrency transactions employ hard hash functions along with ECC and Lamport public keys to resist brute-force attacks. An economic model discourages address reuse and incorporates time constraints to ensure commitments despite network issues.
Highlighting the significance of security measures, a potential vulnerability involving the exploitation of broadcasted bundles by attackers was identified, emphasizing the need for evaluating risks from an attacker's perspective.
Comparative analysis of breaking through the Lamport chain versus conducting a double-spending attack illustrates the robustness of the system, even considering advanced cracking capabilities. While Schnorr signatures were noted for their compactness, concerns about their security level prompted calls for stronger protections.
Contributions to cryptographic protocols in digital currency development have been acknowledged, with references to Needham's MAVE signature scheme, his MAVEPAY cryptocurrency system, and Miller's FawkesCoin.
The correspondence proposes improving byte-efficiency in Layer 1 blockchain protocols by adopting the Lamport Scheme for transaction signing, which could enhance security and optimize space on the blockchain.
Regarding blockchain transactions, a tuple method is introduced, combining ECC keys and Lamport chains, where only two Lamport hashes may be stored instead of a full ECC signature, potentially reducing blockchain data storage needs. This method involves broadcasting a tuple consisting of the transaction, a combined hash, and an ECC-signed commitment. The miner buries most parts of the tuple and includes the signed commitment in a block, incentivizing timely publication of the hash's preimage. Should the preimage not be revealed within the time limit, penalties are applied to the miners from the UTXO. Conversely, revealing the preimage in time completes the transaction obligations. Argon2 is recommended for further optimization, allowing a reduction in hash sizes to 12 bytes each, considerably decreasing the required space for transactions on the blockchain.
